head.title: Encounter at the Gas Pump: Some Views About What to Do

hedline.hl1: Encounter at the Gas Pump: Some Views About What to Do

abstract.p: Barbara D Worden letter responds to Peter Applebome's July 23 column on loud, obscene rap music being played by man at gas pump (S)

block.p: Many readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 23 Soapbox column about racial mores and suburban manners at a gas station in Westchester County. The problem the column posed was what, if anything, to say to or do about the black gentleman sharing his expletive-laden music with the world and also Mr. Applebome's 9-year-old daughter.
Here is a sampling of readers' reactions.

I have been in this situation myself several times. I believe the issue is one of manners, civility and courteous behavior in public, such as saying ''thank you'' when someone holds a door, or lets you go first. I think raising the race card is a bogus issue. In addition, I think the content of the music is irrelevant because the time was so brief, and censorship is another matter.

The problem the column posed was what, if anything, to say to or do about the black gentleman sharing his expletive-laden music with the world and also Mr. Applebome's 9-year-old daughter.
Here is a sampling of readers' reactions.

I have been in this situation myself several times. I believe the issue is one of manners, civility and courteous behavior in public, such as saying ''thank you'' when someone holds a door, or lets you go first. I think raising the race card is a bogus issue. In addition, I think the content of the music is irrelevant because the time was so brief, and censorship is another matter.

I have not asked the offender to turn down the music, at any of the times I was offended. Primarily because the music wasn't that loud and the last time an incident occurred, it was at night, and there was a group of young African-American males and me at the gas station. I wouldn't ask a group of young males of any color to turn down their music, simply because there is only one of me and I'm a midlife Caucasian woman.

The offenders in my situations were usually African-American, but not always. They were always young and male, and I believe it's a poorly intended macho thing. Why not write another article about the generally declining lack of manners and boorish behavior in public places? It would be a good follow-up.
